questions.text: Sickness absenteeism is used as an index to assess?
questions.correct_answer: B. State of health of workers
questions.explanation:
Solution:

State of health of workers Ergonomics means fitting the job to the worker. The objective of ergonomics is to achieve the best mutual adjustment of man and his work for the improvement of human efficiency and well-being. Sickness absenteeism is a helpful index in the industry to assess the state of health of workers and their physical, mental, and social well-being. Causes of sickness absenteeism: Economic causes, social causes, medical causes, and non-occupational causes. Good factory management, adequate pre-placement examination, good human relations, and the application of ergonomics can prevent it.

questions.text: A 42-year-old Sugar cane worker presented to the OPD with a chief complaint of breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and slight fever. Which among the following organism is the cause of the Patients condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thermoactinomyces sacchari The worker is suffering from Bagassosis, which has occurred due to working in a Sugar Cane Factory. Bagassosis has been shown to be due to a thermophilic actinomycete for which the name Thermoactinomyces sacchari was suggested. Symptoms consist of: Breathlessness, cough, haemoptysis, and slight fever. Initially, there is acute diffuse bronchiolitis. Skiagram may show mottling in lungs or shadow. There is an impairment of pulmonary function.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, working for more than 10 years in an industry. Solution:

Asbestosis According to the given symptoms and Signs and Examinations, the disease that the worker is suffering is Asbestosis. And it is due to the inhalation of dust or asbestos for up to many years, probably more than 10 years. Sign and Symptoms of Asbestosis: Clinically the disease is characterized by dyspnoea which is frequently out of proportion to the clinical signs in the lungs. In advanced cases, there may be clubbing of fingers, cardiac distress, and cyanosis. Clinically the disease is characterized by dyspnoea which is frequently out of proportion to the clinical signs in the lungs. In advanced cases, there may be clubbing of fingers, cardiac distress, and cyanosis. The sputum shows "asbestos bodies," which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin. An X-ray of the chest shows a ground-glass appearance in the lower two-thirds of the lung fields.

questions.text: Inhalation of sugarcane dust could cause:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bagassosis Bagassosis occurs due to occupational exposure to a fibrous residue of sugarcane (bagasse); Bagassosis has been shown to be due to thermophilic actinomycete- Thermoactinomyces sacchari Bagasse contains a percentage of silica, innumerable fungal spores, and micro-organisms; Bagasse dust blocks bronchioles, thus leading to bronchitis and bronchopneumonia and impairment of pulmonary function. Prevention and Bagasse control measures: Keeping moisture content > 20% Spraying bagasse with 2% propionic acid (fungicide). dust control personal protective measures

questions.text: White Fingers may result from which of the following occupational hazards:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vibration Hand-arm vibration (HAV) can cause vibration white finger, permanent and painful numbness, and tingling in the hands and arms, also painful joints and muscle weakening. There is also evidence that it may cause carpel tunnel syndrome. Hand-held portable power tools such as grinders, sanders, impact wrenches, and air chisels transmit vibration into the operator's hands and arms. Regular and frequent exposure to hand-arm vibration can lead to permanent health effects. This is most likely when contact with a vibrating tool or work process is a regular part of a person's job. Occasional and/or infrequent low exposure is unlikely to cause ill health. Symptoms include any combination of: tingling and numbness in the fingers; not being able to feel things properly; loss of strength in the hands; fingers going white (blanching) and becoming red and painful on recovery (particularly in the cold and wet, and probably only in the fingertips at first). Symptoms may appear after only a few months of exposure for some people, but for others, they may take a few years. They are likely to worsen with continued exposure to vibration and may become permanent.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man working in the rubber industry presented to OPD complaining of abdominal pain and constipation. On examination, blue lines on gums and pallor and a slight foot drop were seen, Stippling of RBC was also present. Which of the following is the laboratory diagnosis of the given condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Basophilic Stippling in Peripheral Blood Smear

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The given condition is Plumbism or Chronic Lead Poisoning. So the lab investigation of Lead Poisoning is: Diagnosis of lead poisoning is based on the following: HISTORY: A history of lead exposure CLINICAL FEATURES: Loss of appetite, intestinal colic, persistent headache, weakness, abdominal cramps and constipation, joint and muscular pains, the blue line on gums, anaemia, etc. LABORATORY TESTS : Coproporphyrin in urine (CPU): CPU measurement is a useful screening test. In non-exposed persons, it is less than 150 micrograms/litre. Amino levulinic acid in the urine (ALAU): If it exceeds 5 mg/ litre, it indicates clear lead absorption. Lead in blood and urine: Measuring lead in blood or urine requires refined laboratory techniques. They provide quantitative indicators of exposure. Lead in the urine of over 0.8 mg/litre (normal is 0.2 to 0.8 mg) indicates lead exposure and lead absorption. A 70µg/100 ml blood level is associated with clinical symptoms. Basophilic stippling of RBC: This is a sensitive parameter of the haematological response.

questions.text: A man working in a factory manufacturing storage batteries develops headaches, weakness, abdominal cramps, constipation, and joint and muscle pain. options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of this element in urine at any level has no association with possible exposure

options.text: This poisoning is notifiable but not a compensable disease in India.

questions.correct_answer: B. The concentration of this element in the working atmosphere should be kept below 2.0mg/10 cu. Metres of air
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The concentration of this element in the working atmosphere should be kept below 2.0mg/10 cu. Metres of air This is a case of Lead poisoning, also known as Plumbism. It is common among workers employed in manufacturing storage batteries, glass manufacture, shipbuilding, printing and pottery, rubber industry, etc. Increased lead concentration in the blood to 70µg/100ml is associated with clinical symptoms. c/fs: abdominal colic, constipation, loss of appetite, joint & muscle pain, persistent headache, blue lines on gum, anemia, foot, and wrist drop. Coproporphyrin in urine is a screening test. Lead in the urine of over 0.8 mg/litre and amino levulinic acid in the urine of more than 5 mg/litre indicates lead exposure. Lead poisoning has been a notifiable and compensable disease in India since 1924. The lead concentration in the working atmosphere should be kept below 2.0mg/10 cu. Metres of air

questions.text: The greatest non-occupational source of lead is?

options.label: C
options.text: Licking toys in case of children

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gasoline Thousands of tons of lead every year are exhausted from automobiles by burning gasoline (petrol). This is the greatest source of non-occupational lead. Other sources of non-occupational lead are- drinking water from lead pipes and chewing lead paints on window sills or toys in case of children. Normal adults ingest about 0.2 – 0.3 mg of lead daily from food and beverages. The mode of lead absorption can be by inhalation, ingestion, and through the skin. An increase in blood levels to 70µg/100ml is associated with clinical symptoms of lead poisoning.

Naphthylamine Cancer bladder was first noted in men in the Aniline industry in 1895 Now following have been mentioned as possible bladder carcinogens: b-naphthyl amines Benzidine Paraamino-diphenyl Auramine Magenta Industries associated with cancer bladder are dye-stuffs and the dyeing industry, rubber, gas, and electric cable industry. questions.text: An X-ray technician is at risk of developing which of the following type of cancer?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Skin cancer Radiology technicians have an increased risk of developing certain types of cancer, such as blood (leukemias), breast cancer, and skin cancer. Skin cancer is an occupational hazard among gas workers, coke oven workers, tar distillers, oil refiners, dyestuff makers, and road makers industries associated with mineral oil, pitch, tar, etc. Lung cancer is a hazard in the gas industry, the asbestos industry, nickel and chromium work, arsenic roasting plants, and the mining of radioactive substances. Bladder cancer is a hazard in the dyestuff and dyeing industry, rubber, gas, and electric cable industry.

questions.text: Pulmonary fibrosis and Bronchogenic carcinoma of the lung may follow exposure to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Asbestos Asbestos enters the body by inhalation and fine dust. may be deposited in the alveoli. The fibres are insoluble. The disease may progress even after the removal of contact. The dust deposited in the lungs causes pulmonary fibrosis leading to respiratory insufficiency and death; carcinoma of the bronchus; mesothelioma of the pleura or peritoneum; and cancer of the gastrointestinal tract. The disease does not usually appear until after 5 to 10 years of exposure. The fibrosis in asbestosis is due to mechanical irritation. It is peribronchial, diffuse in character, and basal in the location in contrast to silicosis, in which the fibrosis is nodular and present in the upper part of the lungs.

questions.text: A 55 years old man, working in a cinema hall since the age of 19 years, presents complaints of many tiny dots floating in his field of vision that drift through the fields of vision and also flashes of light. On examination, the eyes are red, and the pupils are dilated. He is advised surgery. Under the ESI act, how many days can he be provided leave?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 years Under the ESI act, there is a provision for Sickness benefits under which the insured person is entitled to leave for sickness for a maximum period of 91 days. Still, for certain long-term diseases (a total of 34 such diseases listed under the act) the person is supposed to be provided leave for a maximum period of 2 years. This scheme is known as extended sickness benefits. A total of 34 diseases are included in this. E.g. TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, detachment of the retina, glaucoma. The man in this question is a case of retinal detachment, hence is a candidate for extended sickness benefit for 2 years.
